title: Royal Mail grows parcels deliveries as letters continue to plunge
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 09:01 BST - UK Markets close in 7 hrs 29 mins Royal Mail grows parcels deliveries as letters continue to plunge By Jon Yeomans | Telegraph – 20 minutes ago +0.4000 
Falling volumes of UK letters kept revenue flat at Royal Mail Group 
Growth in parcel deliveries cushioned the Royal Mail against another sharp dip in the number of letters being sent in the UK, the group revealed on Tuesday. 
Parcel deliveries were up 3pc in the three months to June 28, which helped revenues in the division to grow 2pc. 
However, the number of UK letter deliveries fell 5pc, dragging revenues in this part of the company's business down by 4pc. 
Royal Mail (LSE: RMG.L - news ) is forecasting a decline in addressed letters of 4pc to 6pc a year as people turn to other forms of communication. 
The continuing downturn in letter deliveries pushed revenue in the company's UKPIL business - which operates in the UK collecting and delivering parcels and letters through the Royal Mail Core Network and Parcelforce Worldwide - down 2pc. 
But there was better news in Royal Mail’s European delivery network GLS, where volumes grew by 9pc and revenue by 8pc. 
This meant that group revenue was flat for the first quarter of its financial year. 
Moya Greene, chief executive of Royal Mail, said: "In the first three months of our financial year we have seen a continuation of the overall market trends we saw last year. 
“We have benefitted from the parcel initiatives that took effect in the second half of last year and a good performance from GLS. Our trading environment remains challenging and we are stepping up the pace of change to drive efficiency, growth and innovation, while maintaining a tight focus on costs." 
Royal Mail has targeted new sectors for parcel delivery and has opened its network later and at weekends in a bid to maintain share in a competitive market. 
The group’s shares took a hit on Friday, plunging 3.5pc after Ofcom revealed the scope of its forthcoming review of Royal Mail’s operations. The watchdog could impose price caps amid concerns that Royal Mail has no effective competition in letter deliveries. 
Ofcom is seeking views on its consultation , which closes on September 11. 
Royal Mail Group will announce its half-year results on November 19. 
Analysts at Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) were positive about the group’s performance: “Given that the first quarter is a small quarter in terms of activity and that the comparatives get tougher from here in parcels but easier in letters, we regard all of these movements as within the band of expectations.” 
Barclays added: “We believe attention will now turn to the fundamental regulatory review: in setting out the terms of its review last Friday and calling for responses to its six questions by September 11, Ofcom made it clear that, while reviewing efficiency and parcels, the issues around [wholesale and retail] pricing are its main focus.”
